articles.headline: Shiite Refugees Feel Forsaken in Their Holy City
articles.snippet: A visit to Najaf lays bare the needs of displaced Iraqis and the rough road ahead for national reconciliation.
articles.abstract: A visit to Najaf lays bare the needs of displaced Iraqis and the rough road ahead for national reconciliation.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAJAF, Iraq — The men gather somberly at midday on soiled straw mats under a makeshift canvas canopy in a valiant effort to simulate the traditional Arab formal reception room, but here they have no fans to keep the flies from landing, no sweets or tea to offer strangers.

articles.headline: CBS Is Reaching for a New Hit, but the Early Numbers Fall Short
articles.snippet: In an effort to counter a string of bad news, CBS’s chief executive delivered a strong message to his programming troops last spring: find us another hit, fast.
articles.abstract: In an effort to counter a string of bad news, CBS’s chief executive delivered a strong message to his programming troops last spring: find us another hit, fast.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last spring, Leslie Moonves, chief executive of the CBS Corporation, delivered what several executives there described as a strong message to his programming troops: find us another hit, fast.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: Banks’ Plan to Help May Itself Need Help
articles.snippet: Just days after America’s three largest banks announced a $75 billion effort to rescue troubled securities, the plan has struggled to get off the ground.
articles.abstract: Just days after America’s three largest banks announced a $75 billion effort to rescue troubled securities, the plan has struggled to get off the ground.
articles.lead_paragraph: Does the rescue plan for the credit markets need to be saved?
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Making a Loan Only After It Goes Bad
articles.snippet: Some big banks report poor quarterly results and many bankers are surprised. Why?
articles.abstract: Some big banks report poor quarterly results and many bankers are surprised. Why?

articles.headline: Bomb Attack Kills Scores in Pakistan as Crowds Celebrate Bhutto’s Return
articles.snippet: Local news stations said today that 134 were killed and about 400 wounded when two bombs exploded Thursday near a truck carrying the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto.
articles.abstract: Local news stations said today that 134 were killed and about 400 wounded when two bombs exploded Thursday near a truck carrying the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan, Friday, Oct. 19 — Two bombs exploded Thursday just seconds apart and feet from a truck carrying the returning opposition leader Benazir Bhutto, narrowly missing her but killing scores of people and bloodying her triumphal homecoming after eight years in exile.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Salman Masood

articles.headline: Google’s Strong Quarter Widens Gap With Rivals
articles.snippet: The search giant’s surging third quarter profits showed that it was growing at twice the speed of the online advertising market, which itself is booming.
articles.abstract: The search giant’s surging third quarter profits showed that it was growing at twice the speed of the online advertising market, which itself is booming.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 — The gap between Google and its rivals keeps getting larger.

articles.headline: As the Poles Get Richer, Fewer Seek British Jobs
articles.snippet: Since Poland joined the European Union in 2004, more than a million Poles, mainly young, have come to Britain, but a decline in Polish immigrants could be an even bigger problem.
articles.abstract: Since Poland joined the European Union in 2004, more than a million Poles, mainly young, have come to Britain, but a decline in Polish immigrants could be an even bigger problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Oct. 18 — When Piotr Farbiszewski landed here three years ago, he had enough money in his pocket to live for two weeks.

articles.headline: Confronting Ghosts of 2000 in South Carolina
articles.snippet: The state is a painful symbol of the brutality of politics for John McCain, the place that derailed his 2000 bid.
articles.abstract: The state is a painful symbol of the brutality of politics for John McCain, the place that derailed his 2000 bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — When Senator John McCain and his wife campaign in South Carolina these days, people pull them aside to apologize for what happened during the presidential primary here in 2000.
